story:
My Grandma Gill is walking 280 miles around her garden to raise money for Macmillan.

She usually holds coffee mornings in her local village hall to help raise money however, during these unusual times she hasn't been able to.

She has therefore decided to walk 280 miles around her garden instead so that she can continue to support Macmillan.

My Grandma suffers from Polymyalgia and Osteoarthritis so this has been quite the challenge for her. Despite this, it is evident from the worn trail around her garden, that she has begun shuffling the 280 miles.

Duke the dog initially found this rather exciting and loved to follow her around the garden. He has since become quite bored by the idea and now sits on the patio watching on. I'm sure he thinks she is barking mad!

Macmillan is extremely close to my Grandma's and our families heart, as when her husband (my Grandad) was having treatment in London they put her up in a hotel so she could visit him.

Please support my Grandma on her epic hike around her garden.

story:
Our mum Tracey was diagnosed with stage 3 small cell lung cancer on Wednesday 23rd September 2020, which unfortunatly has spread upwards into her lymph nodes in her neck & is incureable.

It will be managed with Chemotherapy & Radiotherapy, with the obvious side effects of chemo she will be loosing her hair. As a family we want to support her in this & 4 of us will be joining her in either shaving or cutting our hair at Zak Dler Hair & Beauty salon in Derby. My mum thought it would be a great idea if we raised money at the same time for  such an amazing charity that already gave us such a helping hand .

We don't know how much time we have left with her, but it will be spent as a family making amazing memories. 

The date is yet to be announced for when this will take place but we will keep you all updated.As a family we would like to thank you in advance for any donations you can make & if you can't donate please don't worry a share is enough🙏

We love you mum 💓

story: A few weeks back I suggested to Sarah we take part in Sober October (Crazy I know!) Sarah then suggested we take part in a 60 mile challenge, walking 60 miles throughout the whole of October (even crazier!) However those that know us will know we love a drink or 3, so instead of just giving up the alcohol and getting our lazy bums out walking for our own personal benefit we decided to do it for Charity! Every 2 minutes someone in the UK is diagnosed with cancer. Statistics show 1 in 2 people in the UK will be diagnosed with some form of cancer during their life time. We have chosen Macmillan as our charity, the work they do in supporting individuals and their families when they are diagnosed is amazing and really takes some of the pressure away from individuals and their families in their time of need. We will be tracking our walks and uploading pictures of where our adventures take us! Wish us luck!

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page for Macmillan.

Manuel Dos Santos Ferreira passed away on Tuesday 29th September 2020 at 15:24 in his home in Northwood, Middlesex with his wife Clarinda, son Orlando, daughter Sylvia, son-in-law Ahmed, grandson Zayd and friend Alice. 

Manuel was diagnosed with Multiple Myeloma in April 2015. For over five years the NHS Hillingdon and Hammersmith Hospital and Macmillan treated Manuel with such love and care. He was strong and always believed he would find a way to get better. We hope that one day with enough research and advances that they will find a way to cure this cancer and save people like Manuel who had everything to live for.

Most of you know I lost my brother to cancer a month ago ..... it’s almost like time has stood still and the saying “ you don’t know what you miss until it’s gone” is so true .....
Many of you know that I’m also doing the London Marathon next year for Whizz Kidz and thankfully already raised a healthy amount so ........as you can see all my marathons have been for Macmillan .
I’ve spoken to my niece Ellie and she in this dark time remembers how kind and caring the Macmillan nurses were at the hospice so with this in mind if you have a spare pound or two ( yes I know it’s tough times but it’s the tough time’s that are taking people too early ) ..... I am working all that day so will have my app active to track me and Dave will hopefully be tidying up the house and running ...... ( joking )
Every marathon I’ve started I’ve always finished no matter how long it took me ....
I’m not asking you to dig deep but just ruffle the surface and think of my brother Darren as I will as I run around work and add to it before and after .....
Thank You xxxxxx

story:
Throughout November 2020 I will run the distance of 250 Kilometres (~155 Miles) which is a daily average of 8.3 Kilometres / 5.15 Miles to raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support.

I am planning to cover most of the miles along the streets and roads near to where I live, and I will run some of the distance on an unpowered treadmill in the gym. I'm not expecting to break the sound barrier with my running pace and I don't think that Kipchoge will ever hear my name, I'm guessing that 8.3K will take me around 50 minutes on day 1, and I can only imagine how long on day 30..... 

All donations, no matter how big or small will be hugely appreciated and will give me even more motivation to put on my trainers each day and head out into the 'bracing' November weather.

I will be sharing my training progress on this page, along with regular updates throughout the 30 days of November.

Thank you for your support

story:
Keeping families together during difficult times is vital. £35 could pay for a one night stay in our patient and family accommodation close to Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH), so parents from Essex and across the UK can stay close by while their child is in hospital. 

Our new Never Far Away: Essex Appeal aims to raise vital funds to support parent and family accommodation at GOSH. £300,000 will give families precious nights close to their children whilst they receive treatment at GOSH. 


We are asking the people of Essex to get behind this appeal, together we can make a massive difference to the families who are going through a very stressful time, if we can ease one worry then it is worth it. Whether you can raise £1 or £100; it will make an impact to so many families. 

A 7-night stay for 2 adults in a budget hotel 15 minutes from the hospital would cost a staggering £815. This is simply not affordable for most families.

Find out more at www.gosh.org/NeverFarAway

story:
For many of those who know me I’m relatively active but not a huge fan of continuous running, so I am challenging myself to run 12 miles every week of October to raise awareness for CRMO. 

October is CRMO awareness month, a disease I have had for almost 12 years, this is why I have challenged myself to run 12 miles a week through out the month. With all funds going to Great Ormand Street, where i was first diagnosed and had most of my treatment. They helped me through the first 8 years of the illness and help so many other sick kids, and make everyone smile no matter how bad it gets.

I would appreciate any donations to such a wonderful charity and if you want to run with me I would love for you to join either in person or virtually. 

If you would like to know more about more story, drop me a message, always happy to spread awareness and talk about what its like!

rememberedPersonSummary.name: James Penny  Quinn
story:
Back in March 2020 Marie Curie nurses looked after my dad when he came home from hospital to pass peacefully at home with my mum Penny. 

Mum really appreciated the support and care that Marie Curie nurses offered and i know they loved popping in to care for dad as mum always had a freshly baked cake for them to enjoy with a cuppa and a chat. 

I know those nurses who supported mum at this time would be devastated to hear that she herself passed away on 19th Sept at St Georges hospital, after a very short bitter attack from Chicken pox. 

She had a whole new beginning ahead of her, after the shock of dad passing.  She'd packed up her house ahead of the new start to be closer to the little family that we have left.  Only to be stolen from us at such a young age! She didn't want to go... she wanted to live, she wanted to live... and she wanted to live for their dream to live by the seaside! 

Unfortunately... things didn't pan out that way! 

They were both very fun, caring and supportive individuals ... and growing up ... life was one big party! 

I'd like for you to donate to these great nurses in honour of my parents and their colourful life!  If you would also like to share a story or your thoughts about them both or individually that would also be a great comfort! 

Thanks! xx

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thank you for visiting our JustGiving page. 

We are so excited that building has started for our new boathouse which will house our new Shannon Class Lifeboat.

Normally we would be seeing you at our annual events and inviting you into our existing station to talk to you about the work of the RNLI and share safety messages whilst raising vital funds so that we can continue saving lives at sea. 

Now more than ever we need your help, Covid has had a significant effect on donations. Our volunteer crews require additional training in preparation for the arrival of our new boat which will enable us to respond to shouts faster than ever and help us bring more people home to their loved ones.

In addition to this training our crews need to best equipment in order to keep them safe whilst they risk their lives to save others - something they do  24 hours a day, 365 days a year.

Thank you so much for your donation - donations on this page will be restricted for use at RNLI Wells.

eventName: Two Girls JOGLE (John O'Groats to Lands End)
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
One late summer evening in Cornwall, after a couple of glasses of wine, we were reminiscing about pre-COVID life. Those days when we could socialise and travel freely and were blissfully unaware of the dreaded term "lockdown". In our frustration with the current situation, we started thinking of different ways we could spend our days, doing something UK based that we wouldn't usually have the time for. Something challenging, we thought, something that would allow us to look back at 2020 in a more positive way...Two Girls JOGLE was born.


The Challenge:

On Monday 09th November 2020, we will be setting off on our 1800km journey (TBC once we have finalised route) from John O'Groats to Lands End, the longest distance between two points on mainland UK, in winter. Averaging about 120km per day. We have very little experience, neither of us has cycled 120km in a day before, let alone consecutively for 16 of them! And we have 5 weeks to train...this is going to be interesting.

The Charity:

We are aiming to raise the equivalent £££ to the number of kilometres we cycle for the global conservation organisation WWF, an extremely important charity fighting to save our world, something we are both pasionate about. The WWF co- produced David Attenborough's most recent film, A Life on Our Planet (if you missed the premier on Monday, it's available on Netflix from Sunday 04th October), a powerful first-hand account of humanity’s impact on nature and a message of hope for future generations. Their work is essential to stop the destruction of nature and to help it recover. 

Thank You so much for visiting our page, your support means everything to us and will be what keeps us going on those long hard days when our bodies are screaming at us to stop. We will be documenting our journey and sharing some of WWF's work through social media, so follow us on Instagram @twogirlsjogle.

For wildlife, for people, for nature. WWF. For Your World.

story:
I'm running a rather different London Marathon for Oxfam on Sunday. Donations to Oxfam and similar charities are way down this year, as our focus turns inwards due to Covid-19. This is despite the damage being worst where the need was greatest already. Please give generously. Thanks very much. 

This'll be my 14th London Marathon. However, it's a virtual marathon, meaning I just track myself running the distance anywhere. Also, there are no qualifying times for me to go for. So, to motivate myself, I've decided to follow in the footsteps of 19th Century lunatic Robert Barclay. He ran a mile an hour for 1000 consecutive hours, the nutter. Instead, I'll run the full marathon distance by running 1.1 miles (1.76 km) on the hour every hour for 24 hours.

The photomontage shows me in 2004, 2005, 2007, 2015, 2016 & 2017.
